captions.text: [MUSIC - CHARITY VANCE, "ICING"]
-Hey, everyone.

I'm Mindy from Cute
Girls Hairstyles,

and we are here with
Sweet Pea today,
kind of for her debut video.

We're going to show you
guys some of the things

we do to keep a
toddler sitting still
while you're doing their hair.
So here we go.

You can see that Sweet Pea is
a very wiggly two-year-old.

So one of the tricks is just
sort of adapting to the fact
that they're going to wiggle.

There's going to
be lots of movement
involved in working with them.

So right now, I have put
her on this little chair.

The chair just kind of
helps keep her contained.

Helps her feel like she
has a spot, versus just

kind of roaming all over the
counter top in the bathroom.

And one of our tricks is
she's-- you are so noisy.
She's a little shoe junkie.

So we have just given her
some shoes to play with.
Here.

Show them how you
put your shoe on.

Now I did her hair yesterday,
and to do these extensions,

it took us about
2 and 1/2 hours,

and we did it all
in one sitting.

We did take a five minute
break at one point,

just to let her get down and
run around and stretch her legs.

So she is a very good child
as far as sitting still--
like, she's just used to it.

So my first tip
would be to make sure

that you start them
at a really young age.

So you can use something
like shoes or a toy

that they really love,
like a doll for them

to play with to just
kind of keep them still

while you're doing their
braids or their pigtails

or whatever it is
you're working on.

And you have to
obviously not care

about what your mirror
looks like when you're done,

because you're going to have
handprints and footprints
for sure.

So one of our other
favorite tricks
is just a simple water bottle.
This just has water in it.
It's not anything scary.

But you can see she's
super used to this.

We'll just give her
this water bottle,

and she'll just sit
there and squirt it

in her mouth over and
over and over and over
while I work on her hair.

And this actually
keeps her really still.

You can see she's
super used to this.

Another idea is just a
simple baggie of hair bands.

Now, I always use the ziplocks,
because you can zip them shut,
and it takes longer to get into.
Here, let me switch you.
Do this one.

Takes them just a little bit
longer to get into the baggie.

You'll probably end up with
rubber bands kind of scattered
all over when you're done.

But if you get the hair
done in the meantime,

and then you train her to sit
still just that much longer,

you've successfully
had a good hair day.

One of the other things
we use is a toothbrush
and a toothbrush holder.

Now, this is called a Steripod,
this little toothbrush
clip on the top.

I read an article one time
that said that research

has shown that in your
bathroom-- if your tooth

brushes are in your bathroom,
there's all these poop

particles and nasty germs
that get on your toothbrushes.

And ever since then, I've been
kind of neurotic about making

sure that my family
has Steripods

on the tops of
their toothbrushes.

So for her, she loves to play
with this because it's just

the perfect size for her little
fingers to grip the Steripod

and pop it off and
pop it back on.

And then she sticks her
toothbrush in her mouth
and runs it around.

The Steripod has a
little compound in it--

like a nontoxic compound that
releases germ-fighting vapors

to clean her toothbrush when
she's not using it or not

playing with it, which makes
me feel better about her using

her toothbrush in her mouth
over and over and over.

If you guys are
interested in the Steripod

for your toothbrushes, I found
mine at my local Walgreens

in the oral care aisle,
and every three months I

have to replace them, so I
go hunting for them again.

I'm going to actually put a
link in the description box

below so that you
can click on that

and see where the
closest Walgreens to you
is that sells the Steripods.

So if you want one
for your toothbrush,
you can buy one as well.
Let's move on into the kitchen.

So now we've moved into
the kitchen, where I also

style and do her hair,
particularly when

we're doing long styles
that take me a little bit

longer than-- like the
extensions took me a while,
so we stayed in the kitchen.

So one of things I use
is just letting her play

with the same things
that I'm working with.

So the brush or the comb
or the elastic holder.
Want these?

Another opportunity would
be to use a computer.

So oftentimes, we'll just
stick a computer on the table.
Yeah, down?
You want it down?

And we'll be playing her
favorite "Baby Einstein"

or her favorite
"Baby Signing Time,"

and that helps
keep her attention
while we work on her hair.

Another option, of
course, is the phone.
Just the famous phone.

So I have on my
phone some baby apps,

and so I'll flip my phone on and
give her the phone to play with

and then she can
play with the apps.

And she actually,
sadly, knows how

to control this whole
thing by herself at two.
Kind of scary.

And of course,
the infamous food.

If any-- if all else
fails, resort to food.
-See ya.
Bye bye.
-Bye.
What's here?
Do you want some?

And again, I put
them in ziplocks,

because it takes them
just a little bit longer

to pry them open, which gives me
more time to work on her hair.

And we try to stick with
healthier snacks, you know,

that aren't going
to get too crumbly

and in her hair
while we're doing it.
There.

And there's all of my
suggestions for today.
Can you say bye by?
Say bye bye!
-Bye bye.
-Say see you later.
-See you later.
-Good luck.
-Good luck.

title: Toddlers: CGH Top-10 Tips for Sitting Still
